choices.D: Mapping of compliance requirements to policies and procedures

questions.question_text: Which of the following is MOST appropriate method to evaluate the potential impact of legal, regulatory, and contractual requirements on business objectives?
questions.answer_description:
A compliance-oriented BIA will identify all the compliance requirements to which the enterprise has to align and their impacts on business objectives and activities.
It is a discovery process meant to uncover the inner workings of any process. Hence it will also evaluate the potential impact of legal, regulatory, and contractual requirements on business objectives.
Incorrect Answers:
A: Communication with business process stakeholders is done so as to identify the business objectives, but it does not help in identifying impacts.
C: Compliance-oriented gap analysis will only identify the gaps in compliance to current requirements and will not identify impacts to business objectives.
D: Mapping of compliance requirements to policies and procedures will identify only the way the compliance is achieved but not the business impact.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
developing a BCP always starts with the BIA because it provides the foundation for everything else in the plan. ISACA emphasizes structure and process, not just individual actions like D

choices.A: Identifying costs associated with continuity requirements

questions.question_text: Which of the following should be done FIRST when developing a business continuity plan (BCP)?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
In the context of an organization expecting to continually deal with severe distributed denial of service (DDoS) attacks from hacktivist groups, the best recommendation to help address this threat is:

A. Implement Internet service provider (ISP) redundancy.

ISP redundancy involves using multiple ISPs to ensure continuous internet connectivity and service availability. In the event of a DDoS attack, traffic can be rerouted through alternative ISPs to mitigate the impact of the attack on a single connection point. This approach enhances the organization's resilience against DDoS attacks by distributing the load and providing alternative pathways for internet traffic, thereby reducing the likelihood of a complete service shutdown.

The other options, while important in a comprehensive security strategy, have different primary functions:

Implementing an intrusion prevention system (IPS) (option B) is crucial for identifying and blocking malicious traffic, but it might not be sufficient on its own to handle large-scale DDoS attacks.

In the situation where an operations manager has requested risk acceptance after the execution of a mitigation plan has failed, the risk practitioner's best response is:

C. Reassess the risk scenario associated with the action plan.

Reassessing the risk scenario is crucial after a mitigation plan fails. This reassessment involves evaluating the current risk in light of the unsuccessful mitigation attempt, understanding why the mitigation failed, and determining the potential impact and likelihood of the risk in its current state. This process provides updated information that is essential for making an informed decision about whether to accept the risk and, if so, how to manage it moving forward.

questions.question_text: Which of the following would be MOST helpful when selecting appropriate protection for data?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
When selecting appropriate protection for data, the most helpful factor is:

A. Data classification.

Data classification involves categorizing data based on its sensitivity, confidentiality, and criticality to the organization. This process is essential for determining the appropriate level of security controls needed to protect different types of data. By classifying data, an organization can effectively allocate resources and implement targeted security measures that are proportional to the sensitivity and importance of the data. Data classification helps in identifying which data requires more stringent protection measures (such as encryption, access controls, etc.) and which data might need less stringent controls.
